Številni bodo na dan spomina na mrtve obiskali grobove bližnjih
01 Nov 2019, 10:10 by STA

Na današnji dan spomina na mrtve se bodo številni odpravili na grobove bližnjih in se poklonili njihovemu spominu. Osrednja državna spominska slovesnost pa bo pred spomenikom vsem žrtvam vojn in z vojnami povezanim žrtvam na Kongresnem trgu v Ljubljani, na kateri bo predsednik republike Borut Pahor v spremstvu državne delegacije položil venec.



Foto: Tomaž Primožič/FPA

LJUBLJANA, KAMNIK > Spominske slovesnosti na Kongresnem trgu se bodo udeležili tudi premier Marjan Šarec in predsednika DZ in DS, Dejan Židan in Alojz Kovšca, načelnica Generalštaba Slovenske vojske, generalmajorka Alenka Ermenc in v.d. generalnega direktorja policije Tatjana Bobnar.
Po slovesnosti bo Šarec položil venec pri spomeniku padlim v vojni za Slovenijo '91, Židan pa tudi pri spomeniku padlim v NOB, pri Lipi sprave in pri kostnici žrtvam 1. svetovne vojne na ljubljanskih Žalah.
Šarec bo že dopoldne položil venec pred spomenik generalu Rudolfu Maistru v Kamniku, Židan pa pri grobnici na Urhu.
Dan spomina na mrtve, 1. november, je državni praznik in dela prost dan. Za ta dan je značilno obiskovanje grobov bližnjih, polaganje cvetja nanje in prižiganje sveč v spomin na pokojne. Praznik, ki je bil dela prost dan že v Socialistični republiki Sloveniji, ko smo ga imenovali dan mrtvih, je v samostojni Sloveniji po navedbah etnologov ohranil podobno vlogo in način obeleževanja kot v družbenopolitičnem sistemu pred letom 1991.
Zaradi večjega obiska pokopališč bodo danes marsikje veljali posebni prometni režimi. Pričakovati je gnečo in prometne zastoje, zato se moramo na pot odpraviti pravočasno. Hkrati policisti, redarji in upravljavci pokopališč pozivajo k skrbi za varnost imetja. Svetujejo, da v vozilih ne puščamo vrednih predmetov na vidnih mestih.

Many will visit the graves of loved ones on Remembrance Day
01 Nov 2019, 10:10 by STA

On this day of remembrance of the dead, many will go to the graves of their loved ones and pay tribute to their memory. The central national commemoration ceremony will be held in front of the monument to all war victims and war related victims at the Ljubljana Congress Square, where President Borut Pahor, accompanied by a state delegation, will lay a wreath.



Photo: Tomaz Primozic / FPA

LJUBLJANA, KAMNIK> Commemorative ceremonies at the Congress Square will also be attended by Prime Minister Marjan Sarec and Speakers of the National Assembly and the DS, Dejan Zidan and Alojz Kovsca, Chief of the General Staff of the Slovenian Armed Forces, Major General Alenka Ermenc, and Acting Chief of Staff. Director General of Police Tatjana Bobnar.
After the ceremony, Šarec will lay a wreath at the monument to the fallen in the war for Slovenia in '91, and Židan will also lay a wreath at the monument to the fallen in the Liberation War, at Lipa's reconciliation and at the ossuary to the victims of World War I in Ljubljana's Žale.
Šarec will lay a wreath in front of the monument to General Rudolf Maister in Kamnik this morning, and Židan at the tomb at Urh.
Remembrance Day, November 1, is a national holiday and is a day off. The day is characterized by visiting the graves of loved ones, laying flowers on them and lighting candles in memory of the deceased. According to ethnologists, the holiday, which was already a day off in the Socialist Republic of Slovenia when it was called the Day of the Dead, has retained a similar role and way of commemoration in independent Slovenia before 1991.
Due to the increased visit to the cemeteries, special traffic regimes will be in many places today. Traffic jams and traffic jams are to be expected, so we need to get out on time. At the same time, cops, police officers and cemetery managers are calling for the safety of the property. They advise not to leave valuables in visible places in vehicles.
